awd_titl_txt: Improving Vertical Velocity Retrievals from Doppler Radar Observations of Convection
awd_abstract_narration:
Weather radars have a variety of functions, from sensing severe weather to providing estimates of rainfall.  One of the main duties of Doppler radar is to retrieve the horizontal wind field.  However, in meteorology it is very important to know the vertical winds to determine how quickly air is rising or descending.  Radar meteorologists have used a variety of methods to estimate vertical winds from radar data, but there is room for improvement.  The researchers in this project will develop advanced techniques to improve analysis of the three dimensional wind field.  The new techniques will benefit research studies on severe weather topics such as supercell thunderstorms and tornadoes as well as potentially improving the initialization of numerical weather models.  The project will also help to train the next generation of scientists by including students in the data analysis.

The research team will address several long-standing issues related to the processing and utilization of radar meteorology products.  This award is focused on minimizing the errors due to non-simultaneous data collection and the derivation of vertical velocity from radar measurements.  Data will be collected from a variety of radar and profiler systems at the Department of Energy's Atmospheric Radiation Measurement site in Oklahoma to address the following research tasks:  1) Designing a new spatially-variable advection-correction/analysis procedure to reduce errors in radial wind analyses, 2) Investigating the utility of the anelastic vertical vorticity equation as a constraint in variational dual-Doppler wind analysis, and 3) Investigating the advantages and disadvantages of ensemble Kalman filter (EnKF) wind analysis versus variational dual-Doppler wind analysis.

por.por_cntn:
This project designed and tested new techniques of dual-Doppler wind analysis with a focus on analyzing the vertical velocity (w). Accurate analyses of the velocity field -- and especially of w -- are important in studies of microbursts, squall lines, multicell and supercell thunderstorms, and other severe convective phenomena. Software designed for the project was tested with numerically-simulated supercell storm data in an observation system simulations experiment (OSSE) framework as well as with real radar data. We gathered a 40 min dual-Doppler dataset of a heavy convective rain event on 4 September 2018 near El Reno, OK, using two mobile Doppler radars (AIR and RaXPol), while a third mobile Doppler radar (SMART-R) positioned under the storm conducted near-vertical planned-position indicator scans to generate a verification dataset. This long-duration dual-Doppler radar dataset was gathered with unprecedented temporal resolution: the slower radar (RaXPol) completed volume scans at 30 s intervals and the AIR completed volume scans at 10 s intervals.

     We explored new procedures to advection correct radar data. In advection correction, non-simultaneously gathered data are shifted spatially using Taylor's frozen-turbulence hypothesis (with or without provision for some evolution) to obtain analyzed fields that appear as if they were gathered simultaneously. However, while traditional advection correction approaches treat the pattern translation components as uniform, our procedures treat them as spatially varying. Provision for a spatial dependence greatly improves the utility of these methods. One new procedure extended a previous two-dimensional scalar-based (e.g., reflectivity-based) technique to three dimensions. A second new procedure was based on a frozen-turbulence constraint derived for radial wind data. Experiments with this latter procedure using AIR data from 4 September 2018 and from a decaying tornado on 27 May 2015 yielded analyzed radial winds with smaller root-mean-squared errors and larger correlation coefficients than in analyses based on persistence, linear time interpolation, or advection correction using constant pattern-translation components. 

     We refined and tested a variational dual-Doppler analysis (DDA) technique that minimizes (i) discrepancies between the observed and analyzed radial winds, (ii) residuals in the mass conservation equation, (iii) residuals in a vertical vorticity equation, and (iv) gradient penalty terms that confer spatial smoothness on the pattern translation components. The vorticity equation constraint was originally introduced to indirectly add information about w to counter the effect of missing low-level data (e.g., due to beam blockage). As in prior OSSE studies in which simulated data were voided across varying depths near the ground, this refined DDA produced more accurate analyses of w than traditional dual-Doppler analysis techniques when volume scan times were short (~ 30 s). OSSEs also showed that the vorticity equation constraint had little impact when data extended down to the ground. The dependence of the DDA on scan time is due largely to the estimation of the vorticity tendency. To reduce errors in that term, the winds obtained from a provisional retrieval were advection corrected using the new three-dimensional technique to times closer to the actual analysis time before calculating the vorticity tendency. However, unlike the OSSEs, in tests with the 4 September 2018 data, the vorticity equation constrained DDA produced more accurate analyses of w even with ample low-level data. This encouraging and somewhat unexpected finding suggests a further benefit of using the vorticity equation in DDA: it may mitigate the impact of observational errors.

     A high resolution (~250 m) ensemble Kalman filter (EnKF) analysis was created for the 4 September 2018 case. In addition to assimilating conventional surface, upper air, and WSR-88D data, RaxPol and AIR data were assimilated at 2 min intervals. Since it is rare to use the EnKF to assimilate such spatiotemporally dense data so rapidly, much of the focus on the experiment design was on minimizing model shock. In all experiments that produced w analyses competitive with the variational DDA w retrievals, however, ensemble spread grew unduly large in unobserved regions during the data assimilation ("catastrophic filter divergence"), resulting in unphysical analyses. Fortunately, we were able to mitigate the effects of these errors on the region of interest by assimilating only every third or fifth volume from each mobile radar, and the best EnKF analysis produced substantially lower w errors than the best DDA. However, the catastrophic filter divergence problem along with the huge computational cost of very high-resolution EnKF data assimilation suggests that sophisticated DDA techniques like those developed herein may sometimes be the more practical method.

     Our project supported the training of one doctoral student and one post-doctoral scientist in STEM areas related to variational and EnKF methods, radar data analysis and assimilation techniques, severe convection, and mesoscale meteorology. The project graduate student defended his dissertation in December, 2020, and is now an NCAR/EOL post-doctoral scientist. The project post-doctoral scientist is now employed at CIMMS/SPC. The project produced 4 refereed journal publications, 1 doctoral dissertation, and several conference presentations and seminars.
